captions.text:
In this clip we're going to talk about whether
skunks make good pets. Most skunk owners will

tell you that skunks make wonderful pets and
are very intelligent, loving, and playful.

Skunks are also very active and curious and
will require a lot of attention from their

owners. Skunks can also pose a challenge to
a new owner by being stubborn and headstrong,

and not easy to train. Skunks want to do what
they want when they want it. Owning a pet

skunk is a long term commitment, as skunks
in captivity can live from seven to ten year.

Skunks also need a good healthy varied diet,
which can take time to prepare and be expensive

to buy each month. If your skunk will have
the run of your house, then every inch of

your home needs to be checked for things that
could harm your skunk, like electrical cords,

poisonous plants, small items that could be
adjusted, crawl spaces where the skunk could

be stuck or escape, and toilets need to be
latched. Skunks could be trained to use a

litter box and are very clean animals. Your
skunk will need to be spayed or neutered and

have its scent glands removed surgically.
There are no rabies vaccinations available

at this time for skunks, so you will need
to make sure that your skunk does not come

in contact with other animals outside your
home. You should also go to great lengths

to make sure your pet skunk does not bite
anyone, as the animal could be seized and

euthanized to check for rabies. Owning a pet
skunk is not for everyone, but if you have

the time to devote to a pet skunk then they
can be a great pet to have.

title: Pet Skunks : Do Skunks Make Good Pets?

comments.author: Jaiden P'Simer

comments.text:
I would want to get a pet skunk, but I don't believe in de-scenting - it's 
cruel to the animal. Can't I just get one and not remove its scent glands? 
They shouldn't spray if they trust the owner (just like dogs don't bite), 
and even if they do, it's just a smell.﻿
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
+yogozarfy for the people who don't mind the smell, chances are that 
they've got strong stomach, and have lost their sense to smell things. 
 LOL!!
comments.author: jydaflyest

comments.text:
+jydaflyest
Hmm, ok. I thought there were some people who don't mind the smell, though
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
+yogozarfy It is different... as in way WORSE.  That's because if a skunk 
is about to get run over, it goes in full defense mode, and gives you the 
full complement, as it would were it trying to fend off a predator.  The 
smell sticks on your car, and even gets on your clothes.
comments.author: jydaflyest

comments.text:
+jydaflyest
Is that a different smell from just smelling a skunk when driving? Or the 
same smell
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
I accidentally ran over a skunk a little over a month ago. Trust me when I 
tell you this: IT IS NOT "just a smell.". It's a good thing I hadn't eaten 
anything, otherwise I would have lost my dinner. But that smell is 
something that you'll NEVER forget. Like I said earlier, it was an 
accident; one that I would gladly take back if I could. I drive by the same 
road frequently, but now, I drive much slower, and come to a full stop 
should I see a skunk trying to cross the road. It was a very painful lesson 
to learn.
comments.author: jydaflyest

comments.text:
+Kayiko
Hmm, I've smelled dead ones on the side of the road before and didn't think 
it was so awful
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
+yogozarfy
lol be thankful. As someone who accident ran over an already dead skunk in 
the road, that smell is horrible. My car smelled like that for weeks. No 
amount of cleaning was getting that smell out, and that was just from a 
dead one. A direct spray is much worse.
comments.author: Kayiko

comments.text: Hmm, I don't think I've smelled anything like that
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
Not sick with a clinical illness, but smells can be strong enough to cause 
severe nausea and vomiting.
comments.author: Ash MacC

comments.text:
+Kayiko
How can something that's just a smell make people sick, though?
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
+yogozarfy  Some of the things Ash left out, the smell from a skunk spray 
can be so bad, that it can actually make people sick. It can have the same 
effect on people as pepper spray does. Watery eyes, coughing, and even 
gagging. If accidentally shot in eyes, forget it. It burns so bad. Unlike 
pepper spray, a skunks spray smell can linger for days and even weeks. A 
skunks spray actually smells like hot burnt rubber and rotten eggs together.

Removing the glands does no harm to the skunk. If they are someone's pet, 
then they don't require their glands. Unlike say.. declawing a cat. Which 
causes pain and suffering to the animal. So there you go. A pet skunk has 
no need for the glands and having them removed does no harm to the animal, 
and will make the bond between them and their owners stronger.. (cause the 
owner wont be timid about getting sprayed)
comments.author: Kayiko

comments.text:
Oh yeah babe of course, but it' not easy.The old way is bathing in tomato 
soup/juice but they also have deodorizers now you can wash in that'll work 
better (I've read). You gonna get a skunk +yogozarfy? Even though I feel so 
strongly about the smell, i personally wouldn't mind at all to have a pet 
one thats been desecented.
comments.author: Ash MacC

comments.text:
+Ash MacC
So there's no way to get the smell off?
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
Much much stronger if it's freshly sprayed at you. Like I said, never been 
sprayed directly but I have come up on a scene with my family's dogs many 
times during my life where they just got sprayed moments before. The whole 
area and animals will smell to high heavens for days. It's enough to 
convince you to stay far away from wild ones. If they say it's completely 
different, not sure where they'd get that from. I've always found fresh 
spray from a live skunk to be much much stronger than roadkill that's been 
there a while but it's not so dissimilar that you wouldn't recognize it. 
But if you decide to find out for yourself, video it, so I can see your 
reaction ;) a reaction to skunk spray video compilation would be really 
funny actually. Be ready to live with the smell for a while too, especially 
after getting wet.
comments.author: Ash MacC

comments.text:
+Ash MacC
Well, I've smelled it on the side of the road, but people tell me the spray 
itself is completely different?
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:
+yogozarfy it's something entirely different on it's own. With a *strong* 
mixture of rotten egg on the hottest summer day. You'd have to smell it to 
appreciate it (sarcasm). I wish I could explain what it smells like but if 
you ever come within nose shot of it you will notice it. I live in the 
southeast so I can't tell you how many times in my life I've been 
driving/riding down the road to pass one that's been hit by a car (poor 
thing, they are definitely cute; we call them "polecats" here too) and 
whether you always see it or not you can definitely smell it come through 
the vents and fill your car for a few minutes. I wish I could be more help. 
Just believe me when I say that if you want a pet one, you would really 
really be better off having it descented. They do that to ferrets and they 
are just "musky". No where near as bad. Not many things are effective at 
removing the smell either.
comments.author: Ash MacC

comments.text:
+Ash MacC
What does it smell like, then?
comments.author: yogozarfy

comments.text:

man, it's a *strong* smell to say the least. And hard to get out lol.
comments.author: Ash MacC

comments.text:
Try a trap with peanut butter and a small lid with thawed apple juice 
concentrate. Leave the trap door latched open until you notice the bait 
gone , then set it the next evening. I have caught the same wild skunk as 
many as three times in the same trap in the same location using just cat 
food. Set a doormat on top of the cage trap and set it next to the house or 
under the porch (so it looks like a hidyhole).

comments.text:
Neutering is necessary particularly the females. Weasels (skunks & ferrets) 
will die if they repeatedly go through heat without being bred - they begin 
hemorrhaging internally. Cats and dogs can be disruptive to the household 
with repeat heats, and more so if they escape to find relief. De-scenting 
skunks and ferrets can be done simultaneously with neutering but is 
optional based on circumstance. De-clawing is totally cruel and horrible, 
and I am against circumcision personally.
